--- title: "Lesson 2: Reading Data" subtitle: Learning the readr package image: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rstudio/hex-stickers/main/SVG/readr.svg toc: true code-copy: false --- We will cover three main options how to importing data: - Built-in Datasets - Local Datasets (downloaded on your computer) - Online Datasets Below are examples on each of these methods to import data # Built-in Datasets The `iris` dataset is commonly used and built into R; no additional downloads are necessary. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} View(iris) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(iris) ``` :::
# Reading Data from Local CSV File ## Option 1: Import Dataset Button Another option is to use the "Import Dataset" button in the environment pane of RStudio. ![](data_import_button.jpg) ![](data_import_pop_up.jpg) The data will now be available to you. ## Option 2: Copy File Path Option The [readr package](https://readr.tidyverse.org/) is the first package that we will learn about. This allows us to read in rectangular data like cvs files. This is the typical way it goes when you have data located on your computer. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) dataset <- read_csv(file_path) head(dataset) ``` ::: :::{.callout-warning} # Windows Users: This will not run ::: columns ::: {.column width="20%"} One backslash `\` ::: ::: {.column width="1%"} ::: ::: {.column width="79%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data1 <- read_csv("C:\Users\name\Downloads\dataset.csv") ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: :::{.callout-tip} # Windows Users: Either of these options will run ::: columns ::: {.column width="20%"} Two backslashes `\\` ::: ::: {.column width="1%"} ::: ::: {.column width="79%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data1 <- read_csv("C:\\Users\\name\\Downloads\\dataset.csv") ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="20%"} One forwardslash `/` ::: ::: {.column width="1%"} ::: ::: {.column width="79%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data1 <- read_csv("C:/Users/name/Downloads/dataset.csv") ``` ::: ::: ::: :::
## Option 3: URL Method Often you get your data from online somewhere like [GitHub](https://github.com/) or [Kaggle](https://kaggle.com/). While there is the option to download the file, then read it from your computer locally, like we just did above, there's also the option to read in data from a URL. A benefit is that less memory is used on your computer. Another is that you can send your analysis with the data being read in from a URL, and others will be able to run the script without any data issues. Below is an example. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) housing_data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv") ``` ::: ## How to Look at the Data? `view()`: this opens a new tab to view the data in a spreadsheet style like Excel `head()`: this returns the top six rows of a dataset, or the "head" of the data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(housing_data) View(housing_data) ``` :::
# Practices First, let's make a folder on your computer to use for bootcamp. I suggest putting it in your downloads folder or your documents folder and call it "R Bootcamp". Next, click the "Session" button at the top of RStudio, then "Set Working Directory", then "Choose Directory" and use your computer's file directory to navigate to the folder you made for bootcamp. This set your "working directory" which basically makes it easier for us to deal with files. ## Practice 1: ðŸ“ƒ Insurance ðŸ“‘ **Instructions**: 1. Click the link to download the insurance dataset. 2. Use the two commands learned from above to look at the data. **Starter Code:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} library(tidyverse) insurance <- read_csv("path_to_dataset") ``` ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="80%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} | age | sex | bmi | children | smoker | region | charges | |:---:|:------:|:------:|:--------:|:------:|:---------:|:---------:| | 19 | female | 27.900 | 0 | yes | southwest | 16884.924 | | 18 | male | 33.770 | 1 | no | southeast | 1725.552 | | 28 | male | 33.000 | 3 | no | southeast | 4449.462 | | 33 | male | 22.705 | 0 | no | northwest | 21984.471 | | 32 | male | 28.880 | 0 | no | northwest | 3866.855 | | 31 | female | 25.740 | 0 | no | southeast | 3756.622 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: **Answer**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code Solution"} library(tidyverse) insurance <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv") head(insurance) View(insurance) ``` ::: ## Practice 2: ðŸš— Honda Cars ðŸš™ **Instructions**: 1. Open this [website](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/CivicCorolla.csv) in a new tab and copy the URL, or right-click and copy the URL. 2. Use the two commands learned from above to look at the data. ::: columns ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="80%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} | Model | Trim | Year | Mileage | Price | |:-----:|:----:|:----:|:-------:|:-----:| | Civic | LX | 2013 | 52911 | 9900 | | Civic | LX | 2017 | 27966 | 15495 | | Civic | LX | 2016 | 21639 | 14995 | | Civic | LX | 2017 | 21893 | 15595 | | Civic | LX | 2015 | 39868 | 11498 | | Civic | LX | 2015 | 26416 | 14000 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: **Starter Code:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} library(tidyverse) bob <- read_csv("path_to_URL") ``` ::: **Answer**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code Solution"} library(tidyverse) bob <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/CivicCorolla.csv") head(bob) View(bob) ``` ::: ## Practice 3: ðŸ¦· ToothGrowth ðŸ˜ **Instructions**: 1. Look at the `ToothGrowth` dataset (this dataset is built into R) ::: columns ::: {.column width="20%"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} | len | supp | dose | |:----:|:----:|:----:| | 4.2 | VC | 0.5 | | 11.5 | VC | 0.5 | | 7.3 | VC | 0.5 | | 5.8 | VC | 0.5 | | 6.4 | VC | 0.5 | | 10.0 | VC | 0.5 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} ::: ::: **Answer**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code Solution"} head(ToothGrowth) View(ToothGrowth) ``` ::: ## Practice 4: ðŸ“š Student Performance Dataset ðŸ§  **Instructions**: 1. Click the link to download the insurance dataset. 2. Use the two commands learned from above to look at the data. **Starter Code:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} library(tidyverse) dataset <- read_csv("path_to_dataset") ``` ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="90%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} | gender | race/ethnicity | parental level of education | lunch | test preparation course | math score | reading score | writing score | |:------:|:--------------:|:---------------------------:|:------------:|:-----------------------:|:----------:|:-------------:|:-------------:| | female | group B | bachelor's degree | standard | none | 72 | 72 | 74 | | female | group C | some college | standard | completed | 69 | 90 | 88 | | female | group B | master's degree | standard | none | 90 | 95 | 93 | | male | group A | associate's degree | free/reduced | none | 47 | 57 | 44 | | male | group C | some college | standard | none | 76 | 78 | 75 | | female | group B | associate's degree | standard | none | 71 | 83 | 78 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: **Answer**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code Solution"} head(student_performance) View(student_performance) ``` ::: ## Practice 5: ðŸ¡ Rent Prices ðŸ˜ï¸ **Instructions**: 1. Open this [website](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/CivicCorolla.csv) and copy the URL. 2. Use the two commands learned from above to look at the data. ::: columns ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="80%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} | Model | Trim | Year | Mileage | Price | |:-----:|:----:|:----:|:-------:|:-----:| | Civic | LX | 2013 | 52911 | 9900 | | Civic | LX | 2017 | 27966 | 15495 | | Civic | LX | 2016 | 21639 | 14995 | | Civic | LX | 2017 | 21893 | 15595 | | Civic | LX | 2015 | 39868 | 11498 | | Civic | LX | 2015 | 26416 | 14000 | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: **Answer**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code Solution"} head(bob) View(bob) ``` ::: ## Practice 6: ðŸŒº Iris ðŸŒ» **Instructions**: 1. Look at the `iris` dataset (this dataset is built into R) ::: columns ::: {.column width="20%"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} | Sepal.Length | Sepal.Width | Petal.Length | Petal.Width | Species | |:------------:|:-----------:|:------------:|:-----------:|:-------:| | 5.1 | 3.5 | 1.4 | 0.2 | setosa | | 4.9 | 3.0 | 1.4 | 0.2 | setosa | | 4.7 | 3.2 | 1.3 | 0.2 | setosa | | 4.6 | 3.1 | 1.5 | 0.2 | setosa | | 5.0 | 3.6 | 1.4 | 0.2 | setosa | | 5.4 | 3.9 | 1.7 | 0.4 | setosa | ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} ::: ::: **Answer**: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code Solution"} head(iris) View(iris) ``` :::
